title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

And do these kids# families not know where they are in the evenings The carrot of working with ACT, the police and wider community to create something positive is on offer for young people.But so too is the stick, eventhis is something that most would rather avoid using.Let#s hope they continue to grow out of getting kicks from damaging things which folk have put their heart and souls into creating for others.Last year#s Remembrance was strange in the pandemic.Maybe we felt the need this year to reconnect with tradition, or perhaps the past  months has offered a little insight into the infinitely more arduous trials faced by those we remembered last Sunday.The fact that so many people came out on a cold day was heart-warming.

title: scotland-women-head-dubai-february-cup-qualifiers
story: THE WOMENS edition of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament will take place on  and  February  at The Sevens Stadium in Dubai.Scotland will compete alongside Samoa, Colombia and the winner of the Hong Kong v Kazakhstan playoff for the last remaining place at Rugby World Cup  in New Zealand, now due to take place between  Octoberndash November, .The Final Qualication Tournament will operate in a semi-final, final format over two match days.This is the first time the womenrsquos edition of Rugby World Cup has featured a Final Qualication Tournament offering teams a second pathway to qualy for RWC  with the winner booking their place in Pool A alongside hosts New Zealand, Australia and Wales next year.Eleven teams have already booked their place at Rugby World Cup , including New Zealand, England, France, Canada, USA, Australia and Wales, who qualied through their final ranking at Ireland , and South Africa, Fiji, Italy and Japan who qualied through their regions.Rugby World Cup  Tournament Director, Alison Hughes, said: ldquoWe are pleased to be able to share the details of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament. A first for a womenrsquos edition of a Rugby World Cup the tournament offers teams a second opportunity to qualy for the pinnacle event and we anticipate a thrilling contest between competing teams in Dubai in February.Tom Burwell, The Sevens Stadium General Manager, said, ldquoWe are hugely excited to host world-class womenrsquos XVs rugby at The Sevens Stadium. It will be the first time such a competition has taken place in the UAE. With the Emirates Dubai s ing over the next two weekends, itrsquos an exciting time for rugby in the region. We are honoured to be working with World Rugby once more in delivering international rugby. With the winner going onto New Zealand and RWC , we are excited to be part of a nationrsquos journey to the very top of the womenrsquos game..removeThe RWC  Final Qualication Tournament will be live streamed across World Rugby and RWC  digital and social s.Rugby World Cup  will be the showpiece event in womenrsquos rugby union s, with the first tickets for Rugby World Cup  selling out in minutes. Tournament organisers are calling on fans to secure their tickets early to avoid disappointment.

title: work-start-soon-gala-fairydean-rovers-stand
story: GALA Fairydean Rovers hope to reopen their iconic Netherdale Stand for the start of next season.The Peter Womersley designed building has been closed since winter  due to public health and safety concerns associated with spalling concrete.A structural assessment was initially conducted in  highlighting the required repairs needed to the stand.Concrete Repairs Limitedhas been appointed to carry out a range of improvements to the category A listed building. The work includes concrete repairs to the stand and turnstiles, drainage improvements and aesthetic enhancements around the stand to restore some of its original features.The work will be funded by Scottish Borders Council within this yearrsquos capital budget along with a contribution from the Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Community Trust.Councillor Gordon Edgar, executive member for roads and infrastructure, said: ldquoAnyone who is familiar with the town of Galashiels will recognise the iconic architecture of the Netherdale Stand and its importance to the town.ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to see work on repairing the building to its former glory progress with the appointment of an experienced contractor.ldquoEnsuring its long-term future by carrying out these necessary refurbishments will allow future generations to benefit from it andthe stand to its former glory.Murray Souter, regional director for Scotland at Concrete Repairs Limited, said: ldquoConcrete Repairs Limited are delighted to be entrusted with the refurbishment of this iconic structure and our team are looking forward to spending the spring and summer months of  in Galashiels working.ldquoTogether with Scottish Borders Council and their design team, we willthe stand to its original glory, looking great, structurally sound, and ready to cope with a full complement of excited Gala Fairydean Rovers fans.The news was also welcomed by Ross Buchan, chairman of Gala Fairydean Rovers Community Trust..removeHe said: ldquoThe stand repair project has been a long journey which began for us in October . The stand is part of our architectural and historic heritage and itrsquos listing places a duty on us, the community, to preserve the structure for future generations.ldquoWe have now reached a signicant stage on this journey, where, Scottish Borders Council have appointed of the principal contractor to carry out the works. We welcome Concrete Repairs Limitedonto the project and look forward to working in cooperation and partnership with them also.ldquoIt will be a day to celebrate when the stand is opened to the public, club and community where we can once again make full use of this very important facility.ldquoThe project has benefitted from working in cooperation and partnership with Scottish Borders Council, Historic Environment Scotland, Fallago Environmental Fund, Live Borders, Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club, Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club Community Trust and our very experienced design team.

title: rugby-fans-treat-weekend
story: A feast of live rugby is taking place in the Borders this weekend.There will be a huge Borders derby on Saturday when Hawick make the short trip up the A to Philiphaugh where they will face Selkirk in the Premiership. Elsewhere Jed-Forest head west to meet Glasgow Hawks.In the National League Division One Biggar host Stirling Wolves, Gala face Ayr at Netherdale, Kelso make the long trip to Inverness to face Highland and Melrose host Boroughmuir at the Greenyards.In the National League Division Two Peebles host Kirkcaldy at the Gytes.In the National League Division Three Berwick are at home to Murrayfield Wanderers.In the National East League One Duns are in the capital to face Broughton.In the National East League Two Hawick Linden are away to Leith.In the National East League Three Earlston host Edinburgh Northern.In the Reserve East League One Selkirk A face Hawick Force and Jed-Forest A face Stewartrsquos Melville in Edinburgh.In the Reserve East League Two Peebles Reds are away to Edinburgh Accies, Kelso Sharks host Gala A in a Borders derby and Melrose Storm are in East Lothian to face Preston Lodge A.On Sunday Kelso Ladies are away to Annan Ladies.Elsewhere Hawickrsquos Lisa Thomson and former Melrose player Ross McCann will feature for Team GB Womenrsquos and Menrsquos s teams in the Dubai Sevens. The group stages will be held on Saturday with the latter stages and finals on Sunday.As always check before you travel to make sure that the game is on.A round up of the results will be available on the Borderand Peeblesshire News at noon on Sunday.

title: 900-keep-safe-places-available-scotland
story: TODAYis International Day of Persons with Disabilities and Police Scotland say that they aim to ensure that people with disabilities or long-term conditions, both visible and hidden, are able to access their police service when they need it.Previously people with disabilities have told officers that they sometimes feel less safe where they live.In response Police Scotland say that they are working with local communities to create Keep Safe places for anyone feeling vulnerable when out in the community. title: galashiels-great-tapestry-ticket-sale-figures-really-good

title: electric-vehicle-charging-points-borders-report-recommend-fee
story: OWNERS of electric vehicles in the Borders could soon have to pay to charge their vehicle, it has been revealed.Selkirkshire councillor Gordon Edgar, the councilrsquos executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport, told a meeting last week that an upcoming report will recommend the local authority charges for the service.The plans could be put to elected officials as early as January, according to Mr Edgar.Responding to an open question from Hawick representative Davie Paterson on the issue, the independent councillor said: ldquoA condition of earlier Transport Scotland grant funding for electric vehicle charging points was that they were free at the point to encourage the uptake of electric vehicles.ldquoThis condition has now been removed and Scottish Borders Council, like other local authorities, should be considering introducing a charging regime.He added: ldquoA report on the issue is currently being prepared and will recommend that the council introduces a charging regime going forward.Mr Edgar told the meeting that the total cost to the council for the charging points last year was pound,.Meanwhile, Borders MP John Lamont says that an out of order charging point at Tweedbank Railway Station is ldquonot helping people in the Borders use electric vehicles.Figures from the Department for Transport show that there are a total of  electric vehicle charging devices available for public use in the region.But Mr Lamont, Conservative MP for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk, says the station charger has been out of action for two months.ldquoI am keen to see electric vehicle use become more practical for people in the Scottish Borders, he said. ldquoHowever, cases like the broken charging point at Tweedbank Station are not helping.ldquoWe need to make sure we have a fully-ing electric vehicle charging network. That is why I have written to Scottish Borders Council to try and get the charging point fixed as quickly as possible..removeldquoAs we continue to increase the number of EV charging points here in the Borders, we must ensure that they are well maintained.The Borders is set to benefit from pound, of UK Government funding to support the development of electric vehicle charging points, according to Mr Lamont.On the funding, he said: ldquoI am very pleased that almost pound, of funding will go towards the expansion of our EV charging point network as part of the UKrsquos community renewal fund.ldquoI also appreciate that Scottish Borders Council will be taking on the responsibility of looking after them.

title: peebles-high-quality-path-network-plans-lodged-council
story: PEEBLES could be set for a number of ldquohigh quality walking trails after plans were filed with the council.Proposals to improve the current network while also creating new paths are outlined in an application prepared by Laurence Gould Partnership Ltd at the request of Benson Wemyss Farms.The current situation in the area to the west of the town is ldquonot ideal, providing an opportunity to link to other routes and improve ldquothe overall quality of the local path network.ldquoThe farm is a strong supporter of hillwalking and public access, having set up the highly successful Tweed Walk in partnership with Border Council [Scottish Borders Council], and has applied to the Agri-Environment  Climate Scheme for grant aid in order to improve public access across the farm, providing improved links and connectivity, improved path conditions and accessible paths for all, a report submitted as part of the application reads.ldquoThe farm has a number of existing footpaths that will be improved via the scheme, but the scheme will also create a number of new footpaths for users to enjoy.ldquoPeebles is rapidly becoming a destination for enjoying the outdoors and the woods around Neidpath are increasingly used as an important asset by the community.The business is proposing to ldquoincrease the value of the path network to the local community.According to the report, the new routes proposed include linking two core paths through the Jedderfield Plantation.On that plan, the papers state: ldquoThere are a vast range of heavily used paths through these woodlands that turn to mush during the winter. This project aims to make them accessible for more people throughout the year.A new path from the southwest section of South Park Wood along the edge of the River Tweed to the Old Manor Bridge is also outlined.Existing pathways to be upgraded are located throughout South Park Wood and alongside the River Tweed, along the old Symington, Biggar, and Broughton Railway line, according to the report..removeThe business farms at Edston Farm, located immediately to the west of Peebles.Holiday lets, a horse livery and a wedding venue are currently operated by the business, the papers state.

title: borders-gift-card-proposed-help-boost-high-streets
story: PLANS for a gt card that allows you to spend money at local businesses will be discussed by senior councillors on Tuesday .The national initiative is designed to help local retailers and high streets, according to papers put to the executive committee before next weekrsquos meeting.People can choose the amount of money to load onto the gt card and spend it within businesses that have businesses have experienced during the COVID- pandemic.ldquoThe idea behind the gt card is to try and encourage people to spend money in the local community, thereby helping to support local businesses and the local supply chain, the report states. ldquoLike any other gt card, you can choose the amount of money to load onto the card.ldquoHowever, the key dference in this case is that the money can only be spent within the boundaries of the Scottish Borders and with businesses that have signed up to the scheme.ldquoThe gt cards will feature a -digit MasterCard number, CVV and expiry date allowing them to be used online at independent and national retailers alike, as long as the retailer has a physical presence in the local authority area and is making a contribution to the local economy.It adds: ldquoOur understanding is that neighbouring local authorities such as Dumfries and Galloway and Midlothian councils have already signed up to the scheme and East Lothian Council already had a gt card scheme in place which they believe to be worthwhile.If approved, it will cost the council around pound, annually to market and promote the scheme, according to the papers.It is proposed that SBC trials the scheme ldquoover the short to medium term.A review of the scheme will be undertaken after a full year of operation to help gauge the success of the project, with the results then presented to elected members. The gt card project was launched in July by Scotlandrsquos Towns Partnership.

title: social-lunches-fun-games-berwickshire-communities
story: BERWICKSHIRE Housing Associationrsquos BeFriend project is joining forces with Abundant Borders to take its Lunch Plus programme to towns and villages across the district.Abundant Borders first started Social Lunches in Coldstream in , with regular visits from BHA BeFriend ndash befrienders, befriendees and staff. Abundant Borders staff and volunteers prepare homemade soup and sandwiches and BHA BeFriend arrange a iety of games and activities for everyone to enjoy.Karen Birch, Chief Officerat Abundant Borders, said: ldquoThe feedback has been incredible, and it is wonderful to be able to support even our most isolated villages and bring hearty food and good cheer to residents.ldquoItrsquos fantastic to be working so closely with the wonderful folk at BHA BeFriend and to be taking social lunches, fun and games to communities across Berwickshire. It is lovely to see people getting back out into their communities, meeting friends, chatting, enjoying freshly prepared food and having a bit of fun together after the couple of years that we have all had.Terri Bearhope, BeFriend Project Co-ordinator, said: ldquoItrsquos so good to be able to see people out and about again. title: winter-solstice-shortest-day-year-2021
story: As the winter months roll in, the nights are drawing longer and the days shorter - meaning thewinter solstice is just around the corner.The winter solstice marks the shortest day of the year in the UK when we have the fewest hours of daylight.The good newsis that after its over, the days continuously get longer until the summer solstice in June.Heres what you need to know about the shortest day in the UK in ...When is the winter solstice in  The winter solstice will take place on Tuesday December  .On this day, Scotlandwill only see around hours  minutes of daylight.Why does the winter solstice happen The winter solstice occurs in the UK when the north pole reaches its maximum tilt away from the sun.While it only happens once a year in the UK, it happens twice a year across the globe, once in the northern hemisphere and once in the southern hemisphere.The term winter solstice actually refers to the exact moment the earth is tilted furthest away from the sun, however it is also sometimes used to describe the day this occurs.During the winter solstice in the northern hemisphere, the further north you travelthe darker it will be.On December  , the north pole will remain dark for the entire day.From this day onwards, the days will gradually grow longer until the summer solstice six months later, following which the days will again begin to shorten.When is summer solstice The next summer solstice will take place on Tuesday June   in the northern hemisphere, marking the longest day of the year.Summer solstice is when the earth is tilted closest to the sun and is the opposite of the winter solstice.

title: storm-barra-record-number-storms-year-uk
story: Storm Barra marks the second storm of the   season, but what is the most storms we have ever seen in a year The latest spell of bad weather arrives less than two weeks after Storm Arwen, which left thousands of homes without power after rare red weather warnings were issued.While storm Barra has not reached red level alert, there are yellow warnings in place across the country for snow, ice and wind.With almost  more months of the storm year to come, heres what we know about the UKs worst year for storms...Most storms to hit the UK in a yearFrom mid-December  to mid-November , the UK saw at least  major storms.This has been deemed by the Met Office as the stormiest period of weather the UK has seen in the past -years.The storms of   didnt have names as they only began being named in .Meanwhile, seven storms hit the UK in  , starting early with  in October alone.What will the next storm be called So far this year we have had storm Arwen and storm Barra, with the next one set to be named Corrie.The names apply to the UK, Ireland and the Netherlands so there is a nod to all these countries in the naming process.Storms are named alphabetically, but only go up to W and missQ and U.The names for the   season are:ArwenBarraCorrieDudleyEuniceFranklinGladysHermanImaniJackKimLoganMeacuteabhNasimOlwenPoacutelRubySeanTinekeVergilWillemien

title: nicola-sturgeon-update-say-today
story: Nicola Sturgeon gave her weekly update to Parliament today amid concerns surrounding the Omicron iant, describing the situation as "another serious moment" of the pandemic.Last week the Scottish government urged people to tighten their compliance with the rules in order to curb the spread of the iant.Scotlandalso introduced travel restrictions in a four nation approach with the other UK countries.Earlier on Tuesday prime minister Boris Johnson said that preliminaryindications suggested the new iant was more transmissible than Delta.This was addressed bythe first minister today who outlinedwhat scientists so far understand about Omicron.As Omicron continues to cause uncertainty in the run-up to Christmas, heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons Covid update today.... Current protections to remain in placeNo changes will be made to the current regulations, however the Scottish government wants the public to tighten compliance with the regulations.The ruleswill be monitored daily due to the new iant, with the government able to bring in further measuresrequired.The first minister said the Scottish government will seek to do what is necessary to prevent the problem, and will therefore "strive" to act both proportionately andpreventatively evenat the cost of popularity."For the Scottish Government, our first principle will be to seek to do what is necessary to keep the country as safe as possible, eventhat is sometimes at the expense of being popular."And second, we will strive to get the right balance between acting proportionately and acting preventatively.". Rise in overall number of casesCases have risen over the past -daysin all age cohorts under .The first minister said: "In total, cases amongst under s increased by % in the past week - and since people under  currently account for more than % of cases overall, that has inevitably driven an increase in the total number of cases recorded.".remove. More details on confirmed Omicron cases in Scotland coming tomorrowMore detailed information onthe number of Omicron cases in Scotland is due tomorrow.In the coming weeks, more data will become available on the hospitalisations and deaths linked to the Omicron iant, with the first minister saying: "In weeks to come - and as the quality of data allows - these reports will also provide details on the vaccination status of, and hospital admissions and deaths associated with, Omicron cases.". Ten fold increase in Omicron in a single weekOmicron cases in Scotland have increased from  to  cases in the space of a week.Like Boris Johnson this morning, Nicola Sturgeon also said that early evidence suggests that the Omicron iant is more transmissible than Delta.She warned to expect a rapid rise of cases in the coming days.. People asked to work from homeThe first minister urged employers whose employees were working from home earlier in the pandemic to allow them to do so again.This working from home advice will remain in place until the middle of January when it will be reviewed.. , new Covid casesOver , Covid cases were recorded over the past -hours, however this higher number of cases was due to a backlog of results which Public HealthScotland expects to clear today.people were in hospital yesterday with recently confirmed COVID-, while were in intensive care.

title: covid-scotland-work-home
story: Nicola Sturgeon is urgingthe Scottish workforce to workfrom home in the run-up to Christmas as the Omicron iant of Covid becomes more prevalent.In a statement on Tuesday afternoon, the First Minister asked employers to allow their staff to work from home where possible in order to help "stem transmission and avoid the need for even more onerous measures."She said: "We already advise people to work from home where practical. Today, I am asking employers to ensure this is happening."To be blunt,you had staff working from home at this start of the pandemic, please now enable them to do so again."We are asking you to do this from now until the middle of January when we will review this advice again."But who exactly was working from home at the start of the pandemic Heres what we know...Who is the Scottish Government asking to work from home The Scottish Government is asking anyone who worked from home at the start of the pandemic to do so once again until mid-January.At the beginningof the pandemic in March , Nicola Sturgeon said that it was up to employers to decideworking from home was feasible.Now, almost two years later, she is once again calling on employers to make the call.At the start of the pandemic, it was largely only key workerswho could go into work, while everyone  was told to work from home.Key workers were ided into three categories:Category Health and care workers directly supporting Covid response, and associated staffHealth and care workers supporting le-threatening emergency work, as well as critical primary and community care provisionEnergy suppliers and staff providing childcare learning for other Category  staff.Category All other healthand care workers, and wider public sector workers providing emergency critical welfare services ,Those supporting our critical national infrastructure, without whom serious damage to the welfare of the people of Scotlandcould be caused..removeCategory All workerswithout whom there could be a signicant impact on Scotland Of course, at the start of the pandemic, non-essential businesses that could not operate from home were told to shut and their employees were put on furlough.This time mass closures have not been introduced meaning people working from home will largely be those who are office-based.How long is the work from home advice in place The work from home advice is in place until the middle of January according to the First Minister.In January, it will be reviewed again.Why hashome working been so strongly advised According to the First Minister, home working could play a key role in curbing the spread of Omicron.After asking people who worked at home at the beginning of the pandemic to do so again, she concluded: "Please - and I really hope this will be for one last time in this pandemic - letrsquos all pull together, do what is necessary, and get each other and the country through this winter and into what we all hope will be a better and brighter spring."

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation

title: musselburgh-duos-gardening-exploits-see-become-internet-stars
story: Eli Appleby-Donald, , and we KathrynAppleby-Donald, , have created a YouTube channel and website ndash The Kitchen Garden with Eli and Kate ndash aimed at making gardening ldquosimple, easy and fun for everyone.From the garden in the Honest Toun, Eli, a digital teaching specialist at the University of Edinburgh, and Kate, head of collections at the Scottish Parliament, have produced more than  videos which focus on gardening, growing food and flowers.Their YouTube channel now has , subscribers, attracting about , views from  countries.Eli said: ldquoWe had a website and blog that we started back in  when we moved into this house.ldquoAlthough, to be honest, we did it for family to keep them updated and never expected anyone other than our family to read it.ldquoKatersquos mum had been diagnosed with Alzheimerrsquos, so the blog was meant as a way for her to see what we were doing.ldquoWe were really surprised when we started getting messages from folk who had found it and enjoyed it.She said: ldquoWe started making videos to share on the blog, again thinking only a few folk who read the blog would watch them.ldquoBut towards the end of , we started to get a lot more people watching the videos than reading the blog, so I tried to learn a bit more about making videos to make them better.ldquoWhen Covid hit and we all went into lockdown, I really missed being in the classroom but I had been working with students who donrsquot normally delve into the digital world and Irsquod been teaching them to make videos and blog.ldquoI was hearing from them about how much that meant to them to have this outlet while they were locked down and I realised that I was getting something similar from YouTube.Eli said they had done a lot on greenhouse growing because, when they started, they were growing tomatoes and peppers.She added: ldquoI also talk about how to grow from seed to save money because itrsquos a lot cheaper than buying plants.ldquoWersquove done some cooking videos, too ndash things like making passata with the tomatoes yoursquove grown or we did easy sourdough during lockdown.She added: ldquoThe videos are meant as a lsquofriend in the garden with yoursquo idea.ldquoWe only make videos about what we are doing in the garden and specically for growing in Scotland.The couple, who got married in their garden, have covered topics such as mulch, how to sharpen your garden tools, how to get your tomatoes to ripen, how to monitor greenhouse temperatures and composting.Eli said: ldquoIt wasnrsquot until we moved to Musselburgh that I fell in love with gardening.ldquoWhen we bought the house, there werenrsquot really any gardens. The front had been paved over and the back was just a lawn. So, I think we were maybe lucky that we got to design our garden to suit us and start from scratch. It helped fire the passion for gardening, I think.ldquoIrsquove been absolutely astounded at how many amazing folk watch our videos every week. We have had loads of lovely messages from folk saying how much theyrsquove enjoyed learning to garden with us over lockdown and beyond, and how wersquove taken the fear out of it.ldquoThere were even a few messages that made me cry where people have talked about their personal situations and what joy they get from our videos, and how they have made me a part of their weekly ritual.ldquoFolk from all over the world seem to really connect with what we are doing and how we are teaching in our videos, so itrsquos lovely when we get messages telling us what itrsquos been like in their towns and countries, and wersquove made some lovely friends from the US and Canada to Australia, India and even Thailand.ldquoIrsquom so, so glad that folk have found happiness and comfort in our daftness.Catch up with Eli and Kate at youtube c TheKitchenGardenwithEliandKate or thekitchengardenwitheliandkate

title: new-members-scottish-youth-parliament-delighted-get-started

title: mary-contini-column-sustainable-christmas
story: We reflect wryly that, often when the immediate present opening is over, it is not unusual to witness the kids distracted with adventures played out with the empty boxes new toys discarded in the corner of the room.I remember the hilarity in our house on Christmas morning in Cockenzie when my brothers, Kevin, Paul, and John Mark, all under  years of age, after an unusually long absence, appeared as Frankenstein and the Incredible Hulk dressed in nothing other than cardboard boxes, toilet paper tubes, red lipstick and black mascara.Their expensive train set, Lego and Fisher-Price garage lay discarded where they had been opened.Those toys have long since been sent to the tip as, I suspect, will many of this yearrsquos toys in the future.Christmas cabins have ed to Haddington town centreDuring the COP climate change conference, very engaged young people were campaigning with great effect to insist governments urgently stop the causes of climate change.They stood with posters and placards frantically shouting for change.They mean it, it is their future after all.The last thing they want are toys which have been transported halfway across the world and made of non-degradable plastic.Fortunately, we have plenty of alternatives on our doorsteps.This year, the Christmas cabins in Haddington are being set up again selling local arts and crafts, gts for all ages and tastes.Cockenzie House is setting up its superb Christmas Fair this weekend, December , as are Stenton and Innerwick communities.Our local high streets are brimming with wonderful independent gt shops fully stocked with locally made treats.We are spoiled for choice. And,you still canrsquot find what you are looking for, an East Lothian Gt Card loaded with lots of money will always be well received.So this Christmas, before you shop, reflect on that toy lsquoelephant in the roomrsquo: it may be made of plastic.

title: tims-tales-fate-thenew
story: It is a famous legend set in post-Roman Celtic times and a version is told in our book East Lothian Folktales, which Mags illustrated.Thenewrsquos father was the legendary King Loth, whom, the story goes, ruled from Dunpelder . Early religious writings tell the story that Thenew was a victim of her fatherrsquos cruel vengeance for what he believed to be her disobedience and wrongful behaviour.One early medieval account by Jocelinus, a monk from Furness, tells us: ldquoBy the kingrsquos command, she was led to the top of a very high hill called Dunpelder, that, cast down from thence, she might be broken limb by limb, or dashed to pieces.But that didnrsquot work, so she was instead taken to the shore of Aberlady and put into the small hide vessel, pulled from the shore and set adrt.Magsrsquo art captures the terror and desperation of Thenewrsquos situation, as her tiny boat is taken by the tide out to the open sea. It is rocked by waves and she clings on for le, the freezing water lapping over her.But thankfully, there is a happy ending to this story. Her small boat begins to drt inland, across the Firth of Forth, away from the kingdom of her abuser and towards the opposite shore, where she lands just in time. There, on the beach by Culross in Fe, she finds a fire with embers still giving warmth.Jocelinus tells us: ldquoThere were, in the neighbourhood, shepherds keeping watch over the flocks. And they beheld a fire lighted close at hand, and coming with haste found the young woman with her childbirth completed, and the child wrapped in rags, lying in the open air. They, moved by pity, took care of them by increasing the fire and supplying food, and procuring other necessarieshellipSt Serf took them in and cared for them, and Thenewrsquos child would become Saint Kentigern.This story is not provable history, of course, more likely itrsquos mostly legend making. Yet unknown truths often lie under the surface of legends and I for one have always seen the universal truths in this story.When I look into the faces of my children, I hope and pray they will never feel the fear and desperation that is on the face of Thenew of being cast at sea with the desperate hope of finding a safe place.And , God forbid, they ever do, I hope they will be met by people like those shepherds.Andever they, or I, were to meet someone in such a desperate situation, then I hope we would be like those shepherds and respond with kindness, understanding and compassion.That, for me, is the truth in this story it may be an ancient tale, but its relevance is undiminished by time.

title: msp-hears-opportunities-blindwells-visit
story: Martin Whitfield, a South Scotland MSP, visited the new town of Blindwells on November .More than , homes are being built on the site, between Tranent, Prestonpans and Longniddry, alongside plans for education and healthcare services, retail and leisure facilities.Mr Whitfield, Labourrsquos Shadow Minister for Children and Young People, Lelong Learning and Youth Employment, saw first-hand the opportunities available in construction, as well as the skills needed to help the industryrsquos growth.The former primary school teacher said: ldquoIrsquom pleased to see that Blindwells is now making real progress and helping to create new job and apprenticeship opportunities for young people.ldquoWith hundreds of houses and new public infrastructure being built at the development over the coming years, the site will offer a wide range of ways to build a career in construction.ldquoI welcome these new skilled jobs and look forward to seeing many more local young people forging a career in the industry.More than  new homes are currently being built at Blindwells, which will feature a new school among its amenities, and work is due to start early next year by Persimmon on another  residential properties.In recent weeks, five acres of land have also been launched for exclusive use by businesses seeking new commercial property opportunities in the county.Once complete, the development could see up to , new homes.Iain Slater, development and estates director at Hargreaves Land, the development company behind the Blindwells scheme, said: ldquoAhead of the first residents moving into Blindwells in the weeks ahead, our team has been hard at work applying impeccable standards in building a town that will be a relaxing yet vibrant part of the East Lothian landscape.ldquoIt was an honour for myself and development director Bruce Lindsay to show Mr Whitfield our progress in making a modern and sustainable urban environment in which families and businesses can thrive.

title: parents-speak-terrifying-road-next-two-schools-following-accident
story: Haddington Road has a mph speed limit but anxious parents of children at Law Primary and North Berwick High Schools are calling for the entire stretch to be made mph.A mph stretch begins about four metres before Law Primary Schoolrsquos gate and parents say there are no speed-slowing measures, resulting in cars ldquohurtling down the hill of Haddington Road, picking up speed and then turning the corner to children crossing the road.A recent incident involving an S pupil has ignited further fear for parents in the area.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: ldquoAround .pm on Wednesday, November , officers were called to a report of a -year-old girl struck by a van on the B, North Berwick.ldquoShe was taken to hospital to be checked over, then later released.An East Lothian Council spokesperson added: ldquoWe are aware that a North Berwick High School pupil was involved in a collision with a vehicle near to the junction of Lochbridge Road and Haddington Road on November .ldquoPolice and ambulance were called to attend and the young person was taken to hospital with minor injuries before being discharged.ldquoShe has since ed to school.A concerned parent, who asked to remain anonymous, said: ldquoFamilies are expected to walk down this pavement with cars, buses, lorries hurtling past at at least mph.ldquoThe nature of the road encourages you to pick up speed as it is wide, straight and goes downhill.ldquoThere are no signs about it being a school area until you get right to the school.ldquoThere are no crash barriers along this stretch of road ndash particularly needed at the bottom of the bank as this is where children regularly fall off scooters and bikes into the road as they shoot off the corner after gaining speed coming down the hill ndash literally not nearly a week goes by without us receiving messages of near misses.Another concern from families in the area relates to Covid restrictions, which mean parents are unable to wait in the school playground to collect their children, unless the child is in primary four or below.This has resulted in packed pavements, with people ldquohaving to step onto the main road to make way for prams, bikes, scooters and dogs.One parent said that the issues had been discussed with East Lothian Council, North Berwick Community Council, North Berwick Trust, the school and parent council, but that no solution had been found.They added: ldquoThere has been no movement in years to try to ensure our kids can get to and from school safely.A number of safety measures have been suggested, including a path from the newbuild homes to take children directly into school premises, a crash barrier along the pavement, a crossing from Lochbridge Road across Haddington Road ndash which is currently overseen by a crossing patrol during peak hours ndash or a reduced speed limit to mph as soon as cars enter North Berwick.Additionally, parents are seeking an increase in signage on Haddington Road to alert drivers that they are approaching schools.

title: charity-pupils-bring-joy-cards
story: Our Community Kitchenhas launched Our Kindness Cards, with hundreds of small cards set to be delivered to care home residents, day centres and more.The charity was set up to reduce social isolation by bringing people together to share fresh, home-cooked food and allowing friendships to form in a kind and caring environment.The themed cards will be delivered during the festive period, with a view to revamping them for other occasions.Elaine Gale, from OCK, which is based in Haddington Bowling Club, was thrilled with the initiative.She said: ldquoThe idea is to spread some joy by working with our local schools in the Haddington and Lammermuir area to produce Our Kindness Cards, which are small, themed postcard-size cards.ldquoThe cards will be handed into schools for pupils to draw or write something positive and these will be distributed to people in care homes, our local hospital, assisted living complexes, to participants of OCK and day centres.ldquoDuring the first Covid- lockdown, some wonderful pupils at Knox Academy decided to write positive notes that were attached to our meal bags and delivered out across the community.ldquoThe feedback was fantastic, with many people saying how much of a dference it made to them during such a dreadful time.ldquoOur volunteer Stuart Pe-Win came up with the idea of a card and we decided to name them Our Kindness Cards.ldquoOur volunteer Carol Lumsden designed the cards and we will be collecting  this week that will be distributed out to our schools and then collected by our volunteers to then distribute out across our community.ldquoWe have had a very positive response from our schools, who are delighted to be involved.The charity played a key role in Haddingtonrsquos resilience efforts at the height of the coronavirus pandemic. Instead of welcoming people through the doors of the bowling club, it delivered hot meals to people in the community.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet member for health and social care, welcomed the new project.The Haddington and Lammermuir ward member said: ldquoThis is a lovely project which promotes kindness and connection between generations. Itrsquos such a simple idea but will have a great impact and I commend Our Community Kitchen for the initiative, and schools for becoming involved so readily.ldquoI hope the children get as much pleasure from writing their messages as Irsquom sure the recipients will get from reading them.

title: covid-scotland-negative-lateral-flow-accepted-place-vaccine-passport-today
story: Currently in Scotland you are required to show proof that you are fully vaccinatedfor entry intonightclubs, indoor live events with + people unseated, outdoor live events with + peopleunseated and any event with ,+ people.But from today a negative lateral flow test result at these venues will also be accepted.Heres everything you need to know...Yes, from Monday December , you can use proof of a negative lateral flow testto enter venues on the vaccine passport scheme in Scotland.Proof of vaccination will also still be accepted for these venues.If using a lateral flow test, it must have been taken within -hours prior to entry.You must report your lateral flow test result on the government website.When you take your lateral flow test, you must report it on the Government website, which can be found here.You will then be sent a text or email confirming your result which can be used -negative - for entry to events requiring vaccine certication.Lateral flow tests are available for free from pharmacies and to order from the Scottish government website.Nicola Sturgeon also said that lateral flow tests would become available to collect in more venues in Scotland, including Christmas markets and sport centres.You can download your vaccine passport on your smartphonevia theNHS Scotland Covid Status App.Alternatively, you can order a paper copyof your vaccine passport via yourvaccine portalor phoningthe specially designated Covid status helpline on  , open from am-pm every day.At the moment in Scotland, your booster vaccine will not show on your vaccine passport.However, the Scottish government has said it is working to change this as soon as possible to ensure the booster does appear on your vaccination certication.

title: bid-renew-planning-permission-substation-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-covid-delays
story: Operator Inch Cape Offshore Limitedhas lodged a fresh planning applicationfor the building after it said it would not be able to meet the current deadline of February.It is seeking new planning permission in principle for the substation, which will bring in power from its planned offshore windfarm off the Angus coast, with a new deadline to be set after September .The substation, which has been dubbed a ldquogiant shed by local community councillors, is one of only two projects to be given the go-ahead on the -hectare site, which was bought by East Lothian Council in .The local authority took ownership of thesite and surrounding land from ScottishPower after producing its Cockenzie masterplan ndash a visionary document outlining community hopes and economic opportunities for it.However, to date only ICOL and Seagreen ndash which also plans to build a substation to bring energy from an offshore windfarm onto land ndash have gained planning approval for a project on the site.ICOLrsquos planning permission was controversially granted by Scottish Ministers after they called in the application, taking the decision out of East Lothian Councilrsquos hands, in .East Lothian Council approved Seagreenrsquos proposals in August this year, citing the fact that ICOL already had the go-ahead for a similar project.However, ICOLrsquos permission runs out in a few months and it said that, due to the Covid- pandemic, it had been unable to produce the detailed designs needed to take the project forward.In its new application, it says that the offshore wind farm, which will have  turbines, will be operational in the next five years, with a - target date.And it points out that the new application is the same as the one, which was approved by Scottish Ministers, so should be given the go-ahead, as well as citing Seagreenrsquos planning permission as a reason to grant its new request.The application is currently under consideration and can be viewed on the councilrsquos planning portal.

title: early-return-pre-pandemic-opening-hours-paying-off-east-lothians-sports-centre
story: East Lothian Councilrsquos arms- leisure company enjoyleisure said that nearly  per cent of its members had ed, compared to as low as  per cent in some local authority areas.Chief executive Bill Axon said that the ldquorisky decision to reopen the centres in the county at normal times had been a success.Presenting the firmrsquos annual report to the councilrsquos audit and governance committee last week, Mr Axon said: ldquoWe are in the top quartile,not the top of the Premier League, in terms of the number of customers who ed to use our facilities, which is touching  per cent, while the average in the rest of the country is  per cent.The committee heard that enjoyleisure had seen an  per cent fall in customers using its sports centres between April  and March , when they remained closed for a large part of the time.However, visitors to its golf courses rose by nearly  per cent, with an additional , golfers using them.The operational loss for the company was pound,, nearly half of what had been predicted at the start of the pandemic.Mr Axon said that the decision to reopen centres at pre-pandemic hours following lockdown had seen a huge rise in people ing to them.He said: ldquoWe were delighted to work with the council on what was a groundbreaking approach because in general, most other organisations similar to enjoy and other local authorities did not open up all of their facilities from the outset and, indeed, provided a reduced service deliveryto its communities.ldquoThat did not happen in East Lothian and our approach was quite clear. We wanted to reopen and give confidence back to our communities that their facilities were opening in a safe environment that they could come and visit.ldquoSo whilst there was a risk attached to the decision, it was great that we could work together to ensure we were ahead of the game in terms of customersrsquo s.Despite the strong , Mr Axon told the committee that enjoyleisure did not expect toto pre-Covid membership or income for another two years.But he said that things were looking up, with the predicted income from September this year, the first month after all restrictions had been lted in the centres, expected to be double the amount taken in August.He told the committee that  members of staff were furloughed during lockdown, equating to  per cent of the workforce.And he praised his employees for all their hard work bringing the sport centres and facilities back into use.He said: ldquoI want to put on record our appreciation of all our staff who have gone above and beyond their duties.

title: brave-teenager-leukaemia-returns-school-first-time
story: Aidan Hogg, , of Arrow Crescent, Musselburgh, has been mainly bed-bound at Edinburghrsquos Royal Hospital for Children and Young Peoplesince he was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia in March.Aidan is now making weekly visits to his family home as he continues to receive intense physiotherapy in hospital.His mum, Emma Davidson, said the Preston Lodge High School pupil was delighted toto his high school for the first time in eight months for a short visit.The teenager dropped by for  minutes to visit staff members, who his mum said ldquohe was desperate to see and thank for all their support.Staff and students at the high school recently banded together to raise funds for Aidanrsquos Magical Gts ndash a project set up by the youngster to provide Christmas gts for over  children at RHCYP.Following a dress down day at the school in October, a representative was proud to announce that pound had been raised for the cause, with a generous donation of pound from a friend of the school bringing the total amount to pound,.Julia Robertson, deputy headteacher, said: ldquoWith those funds we are buying an advent door from the Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity, who organise fun things for children and young people in hospital, and  Amazon gt cards for the gt bags.ldquoWersquore looking forward to welcoming Aidan back into school soon too!Recently, Aidan underwent an important milestone in his recovery when he had his port removed.Installed  weeks ago, the port administered chemotherapy, fluids, antibiotics, and food when the teenager was too unwell to eat.Emma added: ldquoSo many times we have seen him hooked up to dferent things through that port.ldquoI know itrsquos been amazing for the staff to get the things he needs into his body the fastest way but I canrsquot say I will be sad to see it go.ldquoI was so nervous for the surgery but also happy for him and for us all.

title: fate-rail-underpass-depends-new-housing-scheme-decision-dunbar
story: Hundreds of new homes have been built at Hallhill, south of the railway line, in Dunbar in recent years.However, pedestrian links between the new homes and the older section of Dunbar are cost of the underpass would be more than pound million, with part of the cost being covered by the Hallhill North development, which would consist of  houses and  flats.A decision is set to be made on the plans, which come from Taylor Wimpey East Scotland and Hallhill Developments Limited, at a meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee on Tuesday.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who chairs the local authorityrsquos planning committee and represents Dunbar on East Lothian Council, noted that currently the only pedestrian access in the area was under the railway line beside Hallhill Sports Centre.He said: ldquoAs part of the application, the developer will be making a contribution to a new underpass at the railway.ldquoThere will not be enough funding coming from the developer to completely do this underpass.ldquoThat has to be done through grant funding from other agencies and the council themselves.ldquoAt the moment, all the houses from the Hallhill area to get to both the lower primary school and secondary school have to come underneath the tunnel, and children going to the Lochend Campus have to come back through that one.ldquoIt is really congested and we which will come through into Ash Grove swing park area but will be a safe route to get to the secondary school.Drawings and documents for the planning application were first submitted to East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department at the beginning of February last year.The scheme, to the west of the primary schoolrsquos Lochend Campus, originally featured  houses and  apartments.

title: covid-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-update-say-today
story: Last week the Scottish government urged people to tighten their compliance with the rules in order to curb the spread of the iant.Scotland also introduced travel restrictions in a four nation approach with the other UK countries.Earlier on Tuesday prime minister Boris Johnson said that preliminaryindications suggested the new iant was more transmissible than Delta.This was addressed bythe first minister today who outlinedwhat scientists so far understand about Omicron.As Omicron continues to cause uncertainty in the run-up to Christmas, heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons Covid update today...No changes will be made to the current regulations, however the Scottish government wants the public to tighten compliance with the regulations.The ruleswill be monitored daily due to the new iant, with the government able to bring in further measuresrequired.The first minister said the Scottish government will seek to do what is necessary to prevent the problem, and will therefore "strive" to act both proportionately andpreventatively evenat the cost of popularity."For the Scottish Government, our first principle will be to seek to do what is necessary to keep the country as safe as possible, eventhat is sometimes at the expense of being popular."And second, we will strive to get the right balance between acting proportionately and acting preventatively."Cases have risen over the past -days, in all age cohorts under .The first minister said: "In total, cases amongst under s increased by % in the past week - and since people under  currently account for more than % of cases overall, that has inevitably driven an increase in the total number of cases recorded."More detailed information onthe number of Omicron cases in Scotland is due tomorrow.In the coming weeks, more data will become available on the hospitalisations and deaths linked to the Omicron iant, with the first minister saying: "In weeks to come - title: covid-scotland-work-home
story: In a statement on Tuesday afternoon, the First Minister asked employers to allow their staff to work from home where possible in order to help "stem transmission and avoid the need for even more onerous measures."She said: "We already advise people to work from home where practical. Today, I am asking employers to ensure this is happening."To be blunt,you had staff working from home at this start of the pandemic, please now enable them to do so again."We are asking you to do this from now until the middle of January when we will review this advice again."But who exactly was working from home at the start of the pandemic Heres what we know...The Scottish Government is asking anyone who worked from home at the start of the pandemic to do so once again until mid-January.At the beginningof the pandemic in March , Nicola Sturgeon said that it was up to employers to decideworking from home was feasible.Now, almost two years later, she is once again calling on employers to make the call.At the start of the pandemic, it was largely only key workerswho could go into work, while everyone  was told to work from home.Key workers were ided into three categories:Category Category Category Of course, at the start of the pandemic, non-essential businesses that could not operate from home were told to shut and their employees were put on furlough.This time mass closures have not been introduced meaning people working from home will largely be those who are office-based.The work from home advice is in place until the middle of January according to the First Minister.In January, it will be reviewed again.According to the First Minister, home working could play a key role in curbing the spread of Omicron.After asking people who worked at home at the beginning of the pandemic to do so again, she concluded: "Please - and I really hope this will be for one last time in this pandemic - letrsquos all pull together, do what is necessary, and get each other and the country through this winter and into what we all hope will be a better and brighter spring."

title: new-smart-wind-turbine-set-trialled-former-cockenzie-power-station-site
story: A scaled-down prototype of the new windsurf turbine would be placed at the former Cockenzie Power Station site as part of an -month trial, under new plans submitted to East Lothian Council.The innovative design of the turbine has been described by Edinburgh-based producers Swt TG Energy Ltd as a "game-changer".Designer Sam Dickinson said that the company had worked for years to come up with a design which would be more productive, generate less noise and reduce risk to wildle.He said: ldquoThis is a very early prototype we are testing, it is a new form of aerodynamics.ldquoIt will have less of an environmental impact on birdle and noise. If it works, it will be a game-changer.The firm has applied for planning permission to place a miniature version of the new windsurf turbine on the power station site for  months to monitor its effectiveness.Mr Dickinson said that theof time would give the company a full yearrsquos access to trialling the turbine in all seasons on the exposed coastal site.The turbine itself, which he describes as looking like an upside-down egg whisk, features five blades which are electronically operated and computer controlled.The smart technology allows the computer to move the blades with the wind to gain maximum energy from it, as well as monitoring for any kind of impact.Mr Dickinson compared it to having Olympic sailor Ben Ainslie at the helm of five sails, controlling them in the wind during a race to get the best performance.And he said: ldquoThe technology involved means thatthere was an impact from a bird, it would instantly shut down and we would know it had happened. The sameit was struck by a JCB.ldquoThis dfers from the rotaryturbines, which continue to rotate.It is understood that the company has agreed with East Lothian Council ahead of any planning consent that, should an incident occur onsite involving the death of a bird or breach of noise levels, the trial will shut down.The company has worked with RSPB experts in designing the turbine, which Mr Dickinson said had been years in the making.He said: ldquoThis is the first time we are putting our heads over the parapet, as such, with this prototype and publicly revealing our work.The application is for the siting of the lsquonovelrsquo wind turbine on the site for  months only to trial it. title: winter-solstice-shortest-day-year-2021
story: The winter solstice marks the shortest day of the year in the UK when we have the fewest hours of daylight.The good news is that after its over, the days continuously get longer until the summer solstice in June.Heres what you need to know about the shortest day in the UK in ...The winter solstice will take place on Tuesday December  .On this day, Scotlandwill only see around hours  minutes of daylight.The winter solstice occurs in the UK when the north pole reaches its maximum tilt away from the sun.While it only happens once a year in the UK, it happens twice a year across the globe, once in the northern hemisphere and once in the southern hemisphere.The term winter solstice actually refers to the exact moment the earth is tilted furthest away from the sun, however it is also sometimes used to describe the day this occurs.During the winter solstice in the northern hemisphere, the further north you travel the darker it will be.On December  , the north pole will remain dark for the entire day.From this day onwards, the days will gradually grow longer until the summer solstice six months later, following which the days will again begin to shorten.The next summer solstice will take place on Tuesday June   in the northern hemisphere, marking the longest day of the year.Summer solstice is when the earth is tilted closest to the sun and is the opposite of the winter solstice.

story: Itrsquos also distressing to think of these poor folk without heat, light and cooking facilities for more than a week. title: worlds-first-plant-based-covid-vaccine-medicago-approved-trial-aberdeen
story: Medicago, the worlds first plant-based Covid vaccine, was shown to reduce the risk of symptomatic infections caused by the Delta iant by around  per cent compared to a placebo during clinical trials which got underway at the end of May this year.More than , participants in Canada, Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, the US and UK are taking part in the study, including  in Aberdeen, where Dr Roy Soiza, a consultant physician specialising in geriatric medicine, was the lead investigator.: Negative Covid tests added to vaccine passport schemeDr Soiza said: "This is a completely dferent type of vaccine so that in itself is quite exciting."The ability to use plants to produce vaccines is only a few year old, but one of the advantages is that it can produce quite large amounts of vaccine in a relatively short space of time."So for examplethere is a new iant of concern - which of course there happens to be now - it would be possible to change the plant model and scale up production in a short space of time, maybe three to four weeks, which is a lot shorter than other types of production."I know they are planning to produce a second generation of their own vaccine for Omicron and the other iants which are more prevalent now." led the Aberdeen arm of the clinical trial, which had  participants" alt"HeraldScotland: Dr Roy Soizaled the Aberdeen arm of the clinical trial, which had  participants" class"editor-image"Dr Roy Soizaled the Aberdeen arm of the clinical trial, which had  participantsThe technique, developed by Quebec-based pharmaceutical firm Medicago, uses Nicotiana benthamiana plants as "bioreactors" which are first submerged in liquid saturated with bacteria containing a synthesised version of the virus code.These bacteria are then absorbed into the plant cells and the plants transferred to a greenhouse where, after around four days, they begin to release virus-like particles which can trick the bodys immune system into mounting a defence without actually exposing it to an infectious pathogen.These VLPs are produced rapidly and in large quantities by the plants, which are harvested and blended into a solution to create the pure vaccine.Dr Soiza said: "Quite why this plant [produces VLPs], nobody knows, but it can it be manipulated to express whatever protein you need on its surface."For this particular vaccine its the SARS-Cov- spike protein on the surface of the virus-like particle.": New screening rules will severely limit access to GPsAs well as offering a means of producing large amounts of vaccine quickly and comparatively cheaply which can be adapted as the Covid spike protein evolves - the Omicron iant has  mutations compared to the original Wuhan strain - plant-based vaccines are expected to be more appealing to some vaccine hesitant iniduals who perceive them as more natural or who worry about use of eggs or animal-derived substances in development."It was noticeable that this idea of it being a plant-based vaccine was appealing to a number of our volunteers for ious reasons," said Dr Soiza."Some are vegans, some prefer plants on environmental grounds."Phase Two clinical trials showed that participants given two doses of the Medicago vaccine  days apart developed a strong antibody response - around  times higher than those seen in people recovered from Covid - and the Phase Three stage also showed protection of around % against infections caused by the Gamma iant common in Brazil.No serious adverse events were reported and mild side effects were also rare, with fewer than % of participants experiencing fever after the second dose.Medicago, which previously developed a plant-based swine flu vaccine, is now seeking immediate approval from Canadian regulators and is also filing applications for use with UK and US regulators and the World Health Organisation.The vaccine does not have to be frozen and can be kept refrigerated at -degC, making a potential candidate for use in the developing world.Takashi Nagao, CEO and President of Medicago, said: ldquoThis is an incredible moment for Medicago and for novel vaccine s. The results of our clinical trials show the power of plant-based vaccine manufacturing technology."If approved, we will be contributing to the worldrsquos fight against the COVID- pandemic with the worldrsquos first plantbased vaccine for use in humans.: What have we learned about Omicron so far - and how will scientists unravel the rest Heather Morgan, a -year-old university lecturer who lives near Stonehaven in Aberdeenshire, is among those who took part in the Scottish arm of the trial after seeing advert in April  seeking volunteers aged  to .By the time the trial began in May this year, however,the UKs vaccination drive was well advanced -making recruiting and retaining participantsincreasingly challenging.However, Ms Morgan said she wantedto support an "alternative approach" and is determined to stick with the trial in spite of rising Covid rates and the emergence of the Omicron iant.She will not find out until next year whether she received the placebo or the vaccine, but has so far never tested positive for Covid.She said: "I just felt a sense of responsibility that I should take part because I was eligible and I was thinking at the time that were going to need more and dferent types of vaccines and it just seemed that supporting an alternative approach was quite important. is one of the Aberdeen-based trial participants" alt"HeraldScotland: Heather Morganis one of the Aberdeen-based trial participants" class"editor-image"Heather Morganis one of the Aberdeen-based trial participants"I actually had a bit of a wobble around Augustwhen everything was opening up again and I didnt know whether or not I should be doing stuff, but I do daily lateral flow tests and Ive been away on holiday with friends, Ive been into work, Ive gone into cafes and pubs, and done all those things according to the regulations."Im not saying it totally reassures me, but I do want to stay in the trial."

story: Yang Guang and Tian Tian arrived at the Royal Zoological Society of ScotlandrsquosEdinburgh Zoo in  when they were eight, with the hopes they may have a cub.The pair were loaned to the RZSS charity as part of a -year arrangement with the China Wildle Conservation Association, but will nowto China at the end of .# GIANT PANDA UPDATE #We are THRILLED to share that Yang Guang  Tian Tian will stay with us for a further two years before ing to China at the end of .Read our full update and find out more in the FAQs ## https:t.co URkjbTzSUB pic IjYZVoPWmdash Edinburgh ZooDecember , Tian Tian gave birth to a cub in  before she came to Scotland, but efforts to breed from the pair in Edinburgh have proved elusive.A natural breeding attempt was made in , with articial insemination used instead each year between  and .Tian Tian was believed to be pregnant in August , but her hormone levels and behaviour later ed to normal. Phantom pregnancies are common among giant pandas.She was articially inseminated again in  and April this year, but both were unsuccessful.RZSS confirmed that breeding will not be attempted during the final two years of the pandasrsquo Edinburgh stay.:Cold fuels hopes of panda union at zooRZSS chief executive David Field said: ldquoA cub would have generated even more interest in giant pandas and given Tian Tian a wonderful opportunity to be a mother again, after she gave birth in China.ldquoHowever, natural and articial insemination breeding attempts have not been successful and now is the time to move on and just enjoy having Yang Guang and Tian Tian with us for two more years.ldquoWe are very proud of the contribution we have made to giant panda breeding research alongside our partners at the University of Edinburgh, and our findings have been of real benefit to international efforts to protect the species.ldquoWe are thrilled that Yang Guang and Tian Tian will be staying at Edinburgh Zoo for two more years.ldquoYang Guang and Tian Tian have helped millions of people connect with nature, so it is fantastic that they will be with us a little longer before we say goodbye, especially as the pandemic has made it much harder for people to visit them.ldquoIt is encouraging that the status of giant pandas in the wild has been moved by the IUCN from endangered to vulnerable thanks to conservation efforts in China, he added.ldquoHowever, their conservation still faces many challenges, so we will continue to make a substantial annual donation to support this work while Yang Guang and Tian Tian remain with us.:Zoo website crashes as panda fever grips ScotsChina has loaned pandas as a sign of goodwill to several nations, with any cubs born during their stay also considered property of China and must be ed to help further the national breeding programme.The zoo said it plans to convert the giant panda habitat to suit a new species once the pairto China.Mr crucial factor being how we can support conservation in the wild.

title: nordic sea makes its inaugural journey
story: The Nordic Sea made her inaugural journey on the Papay to Westray route this morning, Friday, December .The training and familiarisation of the six crew – two crews of three # has concluded so the vessel will now begin in service on the North o’ the Galt route.The vessel, which was built in , arrived in Orkney from Norway in  as a replacement for the near -year-old Golden Mariana. The Scottish Government via Transport Scotland have funded around half the £. million costs.The council’s head of marine services, transportation and harbour master, Jim Buck, is confident that the new m modern fibre glass vessel will have been worth the wait.“We are delighted to be able to announce the start date for the Nordic Sea. The Golden Mariana has served the communities well, but it’s time now for a younger, more comfortable vessel to take over. At m, with a m beam, the Nordic Sea will be able to carry  passengers and is capable of running at between - knots, which is a little faster than the Golden Mariana. She has stabilisers installed to help with the motion and is a much more luxurious vessel for passengers and, very importantly, is fully accessible for those who require this.”The ship has attracted plenty of speculation, after long periods of being tied up since being purchased in April . COVID delayed a £, refit programme, and further complicating matters has been the retirement of the previous skipper of the Golden Mariana and the longer-than-anticipated recruitment process for crew to serve on the Nordic Sea.Mr Buck went on to explain why the process has taken longer than some had expected.“It would appear to have taken a long time but actually in respect of the certication process when taking a vessel from one country to another it has actually been remarkably quick. She is the first vessel of her type to go through that process and with that comes inevitable hurdles that need to be overcome. The Nordic Sea had a series of modications made to bring her up to the full UK Classication and Certication standard.“She was built to a dferent specication so had to go through the required checks and balances to ensure we met the current specications for the Maritime and Coastguard Agency’s current passenger vessel system.”He is confident that she will be a favourable addition to the fleet.“She is a really good sea keeping vessel with good properties designed with the right centre of height for that comfortable ride.”Councillor David Dawson, chair of the board of Orkney Ferries, said: “I would like to recognise the efforts of the team here in Orkney for getting us to this stage, particularly given the challenges added in by the pandemic, but also for the patience of the people of Papay. We must not forget the faithful service of the Golden Mariana and crew who have served the communities well.“From the information I have received from seagoing staff who have taken the Nordic Sea out in what could be described as ‘challenging conditions’, I have every confidence that the Papay community will not be disappointed in what is a first-class vessel.“We are grateful for the support we’ve received from the Scottish Government and Transport Scotland to enable the purchase of the vessel and are looking forward to the inaugural journey.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: no replacement vessel to cover scrabster route during hamnavoe refit
story: The leline ferry service between Stromness and Scrabster will cease operation completely for a fortnight this winter, NorthLink Ferries has confirmed.The route is to be shutdown from January  until February  while mv Hamnavoe goes into dry dock for maintenance.The vessel#s dry dock period period has proved controversial in recent, with NorthLink#s use of freight vessel mv Helliar sparking concerns over accessibility.Confirming this Monday that this refit period would not be covered by any replacement vessel, the ferry company has revealed plans to expand the Kirkwall Aberdeen route during this period in order to mitigate disruption.Captain John Strathearn, Serco’s operations director at NorthLink Ferries, said: “Dry dock upgrades are crucial to maintain the safety and comfort of our vessels.#We appreciate the impact that the changes have on passengers and the scheduled dry dock period for mv Hamnavoe has been designed to minimise disruption, with Scrabster Harbour carrying out maintenance at the same time and activity taking place during the quietest time of year for both passenger and freight shipments. “During the dry dock period of Monday, January  – Sunday, February , we will operate a revised timetable on the Aberdeen to Kirkwall and Lerwick route, providing daily north and south sailings into Kirkwall.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: breaking newsStaff who worked from home during lockdown should #do so again# urges First MinisterDecember ,  at : pmScotland#s First Minister has urged employers to support their staff to work from home,they did so at the start of the pandemic — until at least the middle of January.This appeal from Nicola Sturgeon comes amid increasing concern over the new Omicron iant of COVID-.
